data.source: European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (COVID-19 cases and deaths); World Bank Government Efficiency Index; Gelfand cultural tightness index; economic and demographic covariates (e.g., GDP per capita, population age structure, population density)
data.wave_or_subset: 141 nations; per capita case metrics; growth rates computed from early pandemic trajectories; mortality model weighted by days since first confirmed case
data.access_details: Data and code reported as publicly available at OSF (Open Science Framework)
data.notes: COVID-19 exponential growth rates converted to linear growth rates; regressions weighted to account for observation variability across countries; mortality likelihood estimated with logistic regression using an exponential distribution; per capita transformations and log transformations applied.

method.description: The study conducted cross-national analyses linking cultural tightness and government efficiency to COVID-19 infection growth rates and mortality likelihood. COVID-19 data were converted to per capita measures and growth rates, then analyzed using OLS regressions with weights. Mortality likelihood was assessed with a generalized linear (logistic) model with an exponential distribution, weighted by days since the first confirmed case. Models included the interaction between cultural tightness and government efficiency and controlled for economic and demographic factors. An evolutionary game theory simulation (20x20 grid prisoner’s dilemma) examined how cultural tightness under ecological threat affects cooperative dynamics.
steps: Assemble country-level data: ECDC COVID-19 cases/deaths, World Bank Government Efficiency Index, Gelfand cultural tightness index, and covariates (e.g., GDP per capita, demographics).
Compute per capita COVID-19 measures and exponential growth rates; transform growth rates to linear/log-linear forms for comparison.
Estimate weighted OLS regressions predicting infection growth rates from cultural tightness, government efficiency, their interaction, and controls.
Estimate a generalized linear logistic regression (with exponential distribution) for mortality likelihood, weighting by days since first confirmed case.
Include and assess economic and demographic controls (e.g., GDP per capita, average age, population density).
Probe interactions (tightness × government efficiency) and generate predicted values (e.g., log cases per million; mortality percentage) for high/low combinations.
Conduct an evolutionary game theory simulation on a 20x20 grid (prisoner’s dilemma) varying ecological threat and cultural tightness to assess cooperation and survival.
Summarize and interpret results, emphasizing the joint roles of cultural tightness and government efficiency.
method.models: Weighted OLS regression for infection growth rates; generalized linear (logistic) model with exponential distribution for mortality likelihood; interaction term between cultural tightness and government efficiency; evolutionary game theory simulation (prisoner’s dilemma on a grid).
method.outcome_variable: COVID-19 infection growth rate (per capita, log-transformed/linearized); mortality likelihood (%)
method.independent_variables: Cultural tightness index (Gelfand); Government Efficiency Index (World Bank); interaction between cultural tightness and government efficiency
method.control_variables: GDP per capita; average age; population density; other economic and demographic factors

results.summary: Across 141 countries, higher cultural tightness and greater government efficiency were each associated with slower COVID-19 infection growth rates, and their interaction further reduced growth. OLS models showed negative coefficients for tightness and efficiency, with GDP per capita positively associated with growth rates. Mortality likelihood was lower in countries with both high tightness and high government efficiency, with predicted mortality around 1.48% versus 2.91% in low tightness/efficiency contexts. Additional analyses reported significant interactions and robustness across specifications. A game-theoretic simulation indicated that tight cultures maintain higher cooperation and survival under increasing ecological threat.
